Posts.Content: Totally understand Aimee. Triple negative tend to have less nodes affected then again, it’s more likely than yours to come back. Good n bad to all of them. Whatever it is - it’s getting dealt with. That’s the main priority. I’ve just had a full Sunday roast and now begging out. With my greasy hair (haven’t touched it since Friday) and a cuppa! Xxxx
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Oh I’ve had my moments but I don’t allow much time for moping. It doesn’t do me any favours. I went to hospital in my furry boots, big coat and a scarf (not a woolly one) just in case I got cold. I didn’t need them to be fair but I did sip on a cuppa. All I would say is make sure they wet your hair through, lather your hair with conditioner and if it doesn’t feel tight, tell them.  It didn’t bother me at all but I’ve a pretty high pain threshold. I think if you’re determined enough, you can put up with anything. I’m doing it to minimise any disruption for the ankle biters so I’ll do what it takes. Just get through the first ten minutes and you’ll be fine. If it works fine if it doesn’t, I’ve already ordered a wig, got eyebrow stamps and eyelashes. Lol x
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hi Aims84 I started my chemo on Friday (EC) and I cold capped. It is totally doable. They were very thorough with the cap, I’m a total needlephobe and was dreading the canulla more than anything. It was doable. It isn’t as bad as you think - I guarantee it. The cold cap is fine. It is a bit uncomfortable but it’s ten minutes to get through. It’s worth it to me to try and keep some hair. I’ve been fine so far since. But of a sore throat, bit of tummy ache, didn’t have a fantastic sleep and ate everything in the house on the first night.  But I’ve been known to do that pre chemo so?! Full kip last night. It’s doable.    You can and will do it x
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hi Aimee The cold cap didn’t particularly bother me. Get through the first ten minutes and you’ll be fine. I know some people have s couple of paracetamols before they go but I didn’t bother. Get a cuppa so you can sip on it but honestly, I’ve had worse hangovers! And for longer - lol.  Just think that’s it’s not permanent and it’s just ten minutes of discomfort and the rest is totally bearable. I didn’t go to bed until about 12.30/1 and literally ate my way through the house! Total scavenger. I woke up about 5/6 but just had a couple of hours later on in th me day. I slept fine Saturday night and have done since. Constantly hungry tho but I’ve eaten well. Take some water/dilute to bed with you. Hope this helps xx
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Aims84 I’m triple negative so hormone treatment won’t help me so chemo was a given. My nodes were clear too. I didn’t take anything before for the cold cap and it’s on half hour before your chemo then an hour after.  Basically it’s on for the duration but it’s only the first ten minutes that it bothers you.  The chemo is belt n braces. I’m sat watching my youngest play footy. Bit light headed but it’s fine. You will be fine xx
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: My first was last Friday ladies. I cold capped and I have been fine. I was back in work Monday, Tuesday and today. I was watching my youngest play football last Sunday. I’ve eaten well, drank water, had a bit of a sore throat, tummy ache and felt a bit fuzzy. It’s doable my lovelies - so far anyway. I’m one week in front of you guys so feel free to ask me anything you want x
Posts.Title: April diagnosis group

Posts.Content: Hi Violetsniff  I requested genetic testing due to being triple negative, pre menapausal and grandmother having a double mastectomy. I was 44 at diagnosis. It should have been offered automatically but wasn’t. You are much more likely to have the mutated BRCA or BRCA1 gene if you are triple negative hence the testing. Hope this helps  xx
Posts.Title: Amount of people with breast cancer

Posts.Content: Morning Vicky I’m triple negative and just started chemo after a lumpectomy to remove the lump. The FEC chemo treats triple negative (mine is just EC without the F but there are other hospitals that continue to use all three). I’m having TAXOL after that (second treatment of chemo - again, this is used for triple negative and has good results). Then radiotherapy. Good for targeted treatment for triple negative although I’m not sure if that is still offered after mastectomy. You’d have to check. Triple negative just doesn’t respond to hormonal treatment so chemo and rads are key.  Hope that helps in some way - there is a group for triple negative people and that might help too. Your FEC is already helping the TN so don’t feel it’s not getting any help! Keep feeling positive xx
Posts.Title: Just found out all my results!

Posts.Content: Just had a Sunday dinner with lots of Yorkshire puddings - all good! X
Posts.Title: Just found out all my results!

Posts.Content: Iceberg11  Having had the same diagnosis as you - I just wondered how you were getting on? There don’t seem to be many of us with this diagnosis. xxxx
Posts.Title: IDC with Medullary type Features

Posts.Content: Hello   I was diagnosed 22nd Feb this year with triple negative Grade 3, 34mm metaplastic bc. A very rare cancer. I had my lumpectomy and Sentinel node biopsy on the 23rd March and am all healed and was back at work this week. I went for my results last week and was over the moon that nodes were clear. I received a copy of the letter sent to my doctor this week and the diagnosis has now changed to invasive ductal carcinoma (medullary like). Whilst this is still rare (about 4-5%) it’s not as rare as previous (<1%). I’m off to see my oncologist on the 19th April. I just wondered how you were getting on xx
Posts.Title: IDC with Medullary type Features

Posts.Content: Hi all Well I’ve been to my oncologist appointment and have to say I was pretty disappointed. Just like you Me63, is come away from my initial meeting with my surgeon with a really detailed plan (pre-surgery). Even with a “if this happens, the next stage is this” “but if thus happens, the next stage will be this). However, I came away from my oncologist meeting without any detailed info other than the two different types of chemo I’d be having (of which I can’t remember the name EC?), that would be for 3-4 months (once every three weeks). I said from the beginning I would cold cap. However, she then said I’d then undergo weekly chemo on another drug (cannot remember this one) and they don’t offer the cold cap with that so would be pointless trying the cold cap on the initial chemo. As I wasn’t expecting this, I didn’t really question it. I’m also anaemic so on iron tablets which is fine.  Feel a bit deflated now as I’d got my head around the cold cap (no pun intended ), chemo every three weeks etc etc and knowing what’s what.  So - bit knacked off today Emma x
Posts.Title: IDC with Medullary type Features

Posts.Content: Thanks for your mail Weeblemum! (Love your name tag). I’ll let you know how I get on xx
Posts.Title: IDC with Medullary type Features
